instructions: Start with your feet together and your arms by your sides, then jump up with your feet apart and your hands overhead.\n\n Return to the start position then do the next rep. This exercise provides a full-body workout and works all your large muscle groups.

common_mistakes.Landing-to-hard: When you jump in the air and come down, you are putting too much impact or pressure on your feet, ankles, knees or other joints, this can lead to discomfort or injury. Try to land the balls of your feet rather than your heels.It absorbs more shock.
common_mistakes.Not-keeping-the-knees-bent: Failing to keep the knees bent can cause the exercise to be less effective.
common_mistakes.Not-engaging-the-core: It requires the core muscles to be engaged throughout the entire exercise. If the core is not engaged, it can lead to poor form and an ineffective workout.

breathing_tips: Inhale as you jump your feet apart.
exhale as you jump your feet back together.
Take deep breaths to fully oxygenate your body.

instructions:
Stand with your feet shoulder width apart and your arms stretched forward, then lower your body until your thighs are parallel with the floor.

Your knees should be extended in the same direction as your toes. Return to the start position and do the next rep.

This works the thighs, hips buttocks, quads, hamstrings and lower body.

common_mistakes.Allowing-your-knees-to-cave-in: This can put unnecessary stress on your knee joints and increase the risk of injury. Keep your knees in line with your toes. Also, do not let your knees go past your toes.
common_mistakes.Hunching-the-back: Hunching your back can put undue stress on your spine and increase the risk of injury. Keep your core engaged and your back straight.
common_mistakes.Not-going-low-enough: If you don't squat low enough, you're not engaging your glutes and hamstrings as effectively. Aim to squat until your thighs are parallel to the ground.
common_mistakes.Letting-your-heels-come-off-the-ground: Lifting your heels can shift your weight forward and put more stress on your knees. Keep your feet flat on the ground.

breathing_tips: Inhale as you lower your body down
Exhale as you push yourself back up
This can help to stabilize your core and ensure proper form

instructions:
Lie down on your side with your head rested onyour right arm. Lift your upper leg up and return to the start position.

Make sure your left leg goes straight up and down during the exercise.

If's a great exercise for the gluteus.

common_mistakes.Raising-the-leg-too-high: This can put unnecessary strain on your hip joint and lower back, which can lead to injury. The recommended height for you would be lifting your leg until you feel a stretch in your leg.
common_mistakes.Rotating-the-hip: Rotating your hip can take the focus off of the outer thigh muscles and shift it to the hip flexors.
common_mistakes.Allowing-your-torso-to-twist: Allowing your torso to twist can cause your lower back to arch, which can increase the risk of injury.
common_mistakes.Not-engaging-the-core: It requires the core muscles to be engaged throughout the entire exercise. If the core is not engaged, it can lead to poor form and an ineffective workout.

breathing_tips: Inhale as you lower your leg back down to the starting position
Exhale as you lift your leg, which can help engage your core and the outer thigh muscles
Avoid holding your breath during the exercise, as this can increase your blood pressure and make the exercise more difficult

instructions: Lie down on your side with your head rested on your left arm. Lift your upper leg up and return to the start position.\n\nMake sure your right leg goes straight up and down during the exercise.It's a great exercise for the gluteus.

common_mistakes.Lifting-the-leg-too-high: Lifting the leg too high can cause your hip to rotate, which can put strain on your lower back and decrease the effectiveness of the exercise.
common_mistakes.Rotating-the-hip: Rotating your hip can take the focus off of the outer thigh muscles and shift it to the hip flexors.
common_mistakes.Allowing-your-torso-to-twist: Allowing your torso to twist can cause your lower back to arch, which can increase the risk of injury.
common_mistakes.Not-engaging-the-core: It requires the core muscles to be engaged throughout the entire exercise. If the core is not engaged, it can lead to poor form and an ineffective workout.

breathing_tips: Inhale as you lower your leg back down to the starting position
Exhale as you lift your leg, which can help engage your core and the outer thigh muscles
Avoid holding your breath during the exercise, as this can increase your blood pressure and make the exercise more difficult

instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart and your hands on your hips.\n\nStep a big step backward with your right leg and lower your body until your left thigh is parallel to the floor. Return and repeat with the other side.

common_mistakes.Leaning-too-far-forward: This can put excess strain on your lower back and reduce the effectiveness of the exercise
common_mistakes.Not-stepping-back-far-enough: Stepping back too little can result in a shallow lunge that doesn't effectively engage the muscles of your legs and glutes.
common_mistakes.Allowing-your-front-knee-to-go-too-far-f: When you are performing a backward lunge, you should make sure your front knee remains properly aligned with your ankle. Otherwise, it can cause excessive pressure on the knee, potentially leading to injury or discomfort.

breathing_tips: As you step back into the lunge position, inhale through your nose. This will help you maintain focus and balance.
As you push back up to the starting position, exhale through your mouth. This will help engage your abs and make the movement more controlled.
Make sure you don't hold your breath during the exercise. Keep your breathing steady and controlled throughout the movement.

instructions: Start on all fours with your knees under your butt and your hands under your shoulders.\n\nThen lift your left leg and squeeze your butt as much as you can. Go back to the start position and repeat the exercise.

common_mistakes.Arching-the-back: Some people tend to arch their lower back as they lift their leg, which can lead to lower back pain and negate the benefits of the exercise. Keep your core engaged all the time.
common_mistakes.Lifting-the-leg-too-high: Lifting your leg too high can put excessive strain on your hip and lower back muscles. Focus on lifting your leg to hip height, while maintaining good form.
common_mistakes.Not-using-the-glutes: Donkey Kicks are meant to target the glutes, so make sure you are actively engaging those muscles throughout the movement. Avoid Using momentum or swinging your leg up.
common_mistakes.Not-keeping-the-supporting-knee-upright: As you lift your leg, it's important to keep the supporting knee steady and still, staying upright at all times.

breathing_tips: Exhale as you lift your leg to help you engage your core and stabilize your body.
Inhale as you lower your leg to help you maintain control and stability as you return to the starting position

instructions: Start on all fours with your knees under your butt and your hands under your shoulders.\n\nThen lift your right leg and squeeze your butt as much as you can. Go back to the start position and repeat the exercise.

common_mistakes.Arching-the-back: Some people tend to arch their lower back as they lift their leg, which can lead to lower back pain and negate the benefits of the exercise. Keep your core engaged all the time.
common_mistakes.Lifting-the-leg-too-high: Lifting your leg too high can put excessive strain on your hip and lower back muscles. Focus on lifting your leg to hip height, while maintaining good form.
common_mistakes.Not-using-the-glutes: Donkey Kicks are meant to target the glutes, so make sure you are actively engaging those muscles throughout the movement. Avoid Using momentum or swinging your leg up.
common_mistakes.Not-keeping-the-supporting-knee-upright: As you lift your leg, it's important to keep the supporting knee steady and still, staying upright at all times.

breathing_tips: Exhale as you lift your leg to help you engage your core and stabilize your body.
Inhale as you lower your leg to help you maintain control and stability as you return to the starting position

instructions: Stand with your right hand on the wall. Bend your left leg and grasp your ankle or toes to bring your left calf close to your left thigh. Hold this position.

common_mistakes.Hunching-the-lower-back: Arching the lower back during the stretch can place undue stress on the lumbar spine and reduce the effectiveness of the stretch on the quadriceps muscles.
common_mistakes.Not-keeping-the-knee-in-line-with-the-hi: Allowing the knee to drift inward or outward during the stretch can reduce the effectiveness of the stretch on the quadriceps muscles. It is important to keep the raised knee vertically down all the time.
common_mistakes.Lifting-the-left-foot-too-high: Lifting the foot too high during the stretch can result in an unbalanced and unstable position, making it difficult to maintain proper form.

breathing_tips: Breathe deeply before you begin the stretch can help prepare your body.
Focus on your breath and keep it steady and even throughout the stretch. Holding your breath can cause tension and discomfort.

instructions: Stand with your left hand on the wall. Bend your right leg and grasp your ankle or toes to bring your right calf close to your right thigh. Hold this position.

common_mistakes.Hunching-the-lower-back: Arching the lower back during the stretch can place undue stress on the lumbar spine and reduce the effectiveness of the stretch on the quadriceps muscles.
common_mistakes.Not-keeping-the-knee-in-line-with-the-hi: Allowing the knee to drift inward or outward during the stretch can reduce the effectiveness of the stretch on the quadriceps muscles. It is important to keep the raised knee vertically down all the time.
common_mistakes.Lifting-the-right-foot-too-high: Lifting the foot too high during the stretch can result in an unbalanced and unstable position, making it difficult to maintain proper form.

breathing_tips: Breathe deeply before you begin the stretch can help prepare your body.
Focus on your breath and keep it steady and even throughout the stretch. Holding your breath can cause tension and discomfort.

instructions:
Lie on the floor with your legs extended. Lift your left knee up and grab it with both hands.

Pull your left knee towards your chest as much as you can while keeping your right leg straight on the ground.
\Hold this position for a few seconds.

common_mistakes.Arching-the-back: As you pull your knee towards your chest, make sure to keep your back flat on the ground. Arching the back can lead to strain or injury.
common_mistakes.Raising-the-head: Avoid lifting your head off the ground as you bring your knee towards your chest. This can cause tension in the neck and shoulders.
common_mistakes.Not-holding-the-stretch-long-enough: It's important to hold the stretch for at least 15-30 seconds to allow the muscles to fully relax and lengthen.

breathing_tips: Breathe deeply and slowly while holding the stretch
Do not hold your breath. Holding your breath can cause your body to tense up and make the exercise more difficult.

instructions:
Lie on the floor with your legs extended. Lift your right knee up and grab it with both hands.

Pull your right knee towards your chest as much as you can while keeping your left straight on the ground.
\Hold this position for a few seconds.

common_mistakes.Arching-the-back: As you pull your knee towards your chest, make sure to keep your back flat on the ground. Arching the back can lead to strain or injury.
common_mistakes.Raising-the-head: Avoid lifting your head off the ground as you bring your knee towards your chest. This can cause tension in the neck and shoulders.
common_mistakes.Not-holding-the-stretch-long-enough: It's important to hold the stretch for at least 15-30 seconds to allow the muscles to fully relax and lengthen.

breathing_tips: Breathe deeply and slowly while holding the stretch
Do not hold your breath. Holding your breath can cause your body to tense up and make the exercise more difficult.
